entry.summary: The CIA will have no comment, spokesman Chris White told The Associated Press.

entry.title: Pakistan judge: Charge CIA lawyer, officer for drone strike
entry.summary:
The legal action comes as the number of CIA drone strikes in Pakistan has fallen precipitously from their 2010 high, amid signs that the U.S. and Pakistan have been more closely cooperating on counterterrorism issues after years of tensions.

The case recalls legal charges brought by an independent magistrate in Italy against CIA officers involved in the 2003 kidnapping of a terror suspect.

entry.title: Pakistan judge orders charges against ex-CIA lawyer over drone deaths
entry.summary: A Pakistani judge on Tuesday ordered criminal charges to be filed against a former CIA lawyer who oversaw the agency's drone program and a former station chief in Islamabad over a 2009 strike that killed two people.

entry.title: Pakistan judge: Charge CIA lawyer, agent for drone strike
entry.summary: The CIA didn't move Bank, who had previously served in Baghdad, until he began receiving death threats.

entry.title: Pakistan judge orders former CIA lawyer, agent be charged

entry.title: Pakistan judge orders former CIA lawyer, agent be charged
entry.summary:
The disclosure didn't prevent Bank from landing another sensitive job: He became chief of the Iran operations division at CIA headquarters at Langley.

The CIA's drone strike program killed Pakistani Taliban fighters and other militants hiding in its tribal regions, but caused major anger across Pakistan over civilian casualties from the strikes.

entry.title: Pakistan judge orders former CIA lawyer, agent be charged
entry.summary: The CIA declined to immediately comment when reached by The Associated Press.

entry.title: Pakistan judge orders former CIA lawyer, agent be charged
entry.summary:
Bank fled Pakistan in 2010 after his cover was blown when the man named Kareem Khan initially threatened to sue the CIA over the deaths of his brother and his son in a purported 2009 strike.

Rizzo was the CIA's acting general counsel overseeing its drone program.

entry.title: CIA agents tried to stop arrest and torture of Canadian Maher Arar, ex-spy says
entry.summary:
- A former spy has described the debate within the CIA over the arrest, rendition and torture of Canadian Maher Arar, saying multiple colleagues warned against it because they were convinced they were punishing an innocent man.

He also made a fleeting reference to a Hollywood hit: "As you may have seen in the movie 'Zero Dark Thirty,' there were certain people inside the CIA who insisted on pushing forward."

entry.title: CIA chief announces sweeping reorganization of US spy agency
entry.summary: The agency's greatest public success of recent years " the 10-year effort to locate and kill Osama bin Laden in 2011 " may have taken longer than it should have, according to evidence made public in the recent Senate report on CIA interrogations.

entry.title: Al Qaeda got $1million in CIA money from fund to free Afghan diplomat
entry.summary: The money the CIA delivered while President Hamid Karzai was in charge was used to buy the support of warlords, legislators and others, as well as expenses for clandestine diplomatic trips and housing for senior officials.

entry.title: Afghanistan gave CIA money to al Qaeda for diplomat's ransom: NYT
entry.summary:
Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden had at first been concerned about the payment, fearing the CIA knew about the money and had tainted it with poison, radiation or a tracking device, the Times said, and suggested it be converted to another currency.

He was released two years later after Afghanistan paid al Qaeda $5 million, a fifth of which was CIA money that came from an Afghan government fund that received monthly cash deliveries from the agency, the Times said.

In addition to the al Qaeda correspondence, the Times said its story was based on conversations with Afghan and Western officials but that the CIA declined to comment.

entry.title: CIA chief: Social media hampers fight against 'terror'
entry.summary:
John Brennan, the CIA director, said such communications only added to the difficulty of dealing with diffuse threats and attacks across the world from groups like the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) and others.

And while agencies such as the CIA have worked to boost their capability of fighting cyber-based threats, those bent on committing "acts of terror" have used technologies to romanticise their ideology, he added.

entry.title: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade, claim Edward Snowden papers
entry.summary: The CIA did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

Carrie no longer CIA officer in next season of 'Homeland'
entry.summary: Gansa later told the PaleyFest audience that CIA officer Carrie Mathison, played by series star Claire Danes, will no longer be an intelligence officer.

entry.title: Danes no longer CIA officer in next 'Homeland'
CIA chief orders sweeping changes
entry.summary:
Director John Brennan announced the restructuring to the agency's workforce, including a new directorate devoted to boosting the CIA's computer hacking skills.

The changes come against a backdrop of evidence that the CIA's focus on hunting and killing terrorists since the September 11 attacks has led to an erosion of the espionage and analytic capabilities the agency built during the Cold War.

entry.title: CIA plans major reorganisation and a focus on digital espionage
entry.summary:
CIA Director John Brennan has outlined a plan for the reorganisation of the agency.

The plans were unveiled by CIA director John Brennan to a workforce in which thousands of employees are likely to see changes in which departments they work for, the lines of authority they report to and even where they sit.

The CIA will also create a new directorate focused exclusively on exploiting advances in computer technology and communications.

The Directorate of Digital Innovation will rank alongside the agency's operations and analysis branches, and be responsible for missions ranging from cyber-espionage to the security of the CIA's internal email.

The head of the CIA's clandestine service recently decided to retire abruptly in part because of opposition to a plan that would strip his position of much of its authority over the agency's covert operations overseas and the teams of spies that it deploys.

entry.title: CIA to make sweeping changes, focus more on cyberops
entry.summary: Brennan told reporters he is creating new units within the CIA, called "mission centers," intended to concentrate the agency's focus on specific challenges or geographic areas, such as weapons proliferation or Africa.

entry.title: CIA to create a digital spy division
entry.summary: "We must place our activities and operations in the digital domain at the very center of all our mission endeavors," Brennan told the CIA workforce on Friday.

entry.title: CIA director announces overhaul of spy agency
entry.summary:
Briefing reporters with Cohen at CIA headquarters this week, Brennan said the changes are necessary to address intelligence gaps that the CIA is not covering.

Most stations are in U.S. embassies, and various CIA case officers in embassies may be working on different missions for different centers.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief may avoid prison for leaking military secrets
entry.summary:
By comparison, former CIA officer John Kiriakou pleaded guilty in 2012 to one count of intentionally disclosing the identity of a covert agent to a reporter and was sentenced to 30 months in prison.

Then the CIA director, Petraeus hailed the conviction as a victory for the agency.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief admits sharing military secrets with mistress
entry.summary: Prosecutors said that after resigning from the CIA, Petraeus signed a form falsely attesting he had no classified material.

entry.title: Petraeus OKs guilty plea in data leak to mistress
entry.summary:
David Petraeus, the former CIA director and top Army general whose affair with his biographer brought down what many considered a bright political future, has agreed to plead guilty to mishandling classified materials.

When Petraeus resigned from the CIA, he signed a security exit form indicating he had no classified material in his possession.

entry.title: Ex-CIA director David Petraeus to plead guilty to giving top secret files to his biographer and mistress
entry.summary: Both have publicly apologized and said their romantic relationship began only after he retired from the military and started at the CIA.

entry.title: Former CIA director Petraeus pleads guilty to federal charge: DOJ
entry.summary:
Petraeus quit as CIA director under President Barack Obama in November 2012 after the affair was discovered.

Another former CIA director, John Deutch, was accused of mishandling classified material and agreed to plead guilty, but President Bill Clinton stepped in and pardoned him in 2001.

The court documents also said Petraeus lied to FBI investigators in October 2012, shortly before he quit the CIA, by saying he had never given classified information to his mistress.

entry.title: Justice Department: Ex-CIA Chief Petraeus to Plead Guilty to Mishandling Classified Materials
Poland to pay $262,000 to inmates held at secret CIA prison
entry.summary: Since 2008, Polish prosecutors have been investigating whether Poland hosted a secret CIA prison, in violation of its laws.

entry.title: Poland to pay $262,000 to inmates held at secret CIA prison
European court rejects Polish appeal in CIA jail case
entry.summary:
The court's decision will add to pressure on other European countries to end years of secrecy about their involvement in the CIA's global program of secret detention after the Sept.

After the release of the Senate report, former Polish president Aleksander Kwasniewski and former prime minister Leszek Miller acknowledged for the first time that they knew the CIA had been holding people on Polish soil.

"This judgment sends a message loud and clear that European states that collaborated in the CIA torture program cannot evade accountability," said Singh.
